review_title: What an awful place to work at.
pros:
They’ll hire you right away, no (or few) questions asked.
If you like exercise, you’ll get plenty of it.
cons: They treat you like animals. More than once I’ve been referred to as a “horse” by management and training. Supervising apparently consists of screaming at the employees as hard and frequently as you can. “Orientation” is not training at all (unless you consider a guy playing decade-old corporate videos and passing on the answers to tests as training). The time assigned to orientation is actually an excuse to get you to sign dozens of documents saying you’ve been extensively trained and are aware of all security procedures - which you’re obviously not - as a way of clearing the company from all liability should you get hurt when trying to figure out how to use the (scarce and poorly maintained) equipment. To make sure there won’t be any issues, they force you to check your phone at security (“check” meaning tossing it inside a makeshift envelope and holding it closed with a recycled identification sticker). Working hours are recorded in chaotic ways, the card swiping being constantly replaced by someone telling you “i made a note of the time you’re leaving, no need to swipe”. Truly appalling, and they couldn’t care less.

pros: workout - fun - music - contest - speed

job_title: ISR- Inside Sales Representative in Greenville, SC
pros: The pay is decent depending on your territory. At least you have a base pay so you aren’t totally screwed. The last couple of years have been a slap in the face for bonuses. They even said ‘inside sales makes too much money’ and now they’re laying people off and shrunk the amount of positions. And then carol tome comes in and starts ‘trimming fat’, by reshaping the organization so shareholders and herself make money. Great job doubling the stock price but at what cost? You lost a lot of fantastic employees. Management is ok depending on what team you are on. Expect micromanaging after a few months after starting. You can make the company a million dollars a year but if you don’t make a certain amount of ‘dials’ they will call you out. They will tell you that you can ‘run the territory how you want’ but give you a list to call. Then they will ask you why you aren’t calling the list. Frustrating, typical corporate structure. Most of the people are great but it’s very corporate like and the managers cannot do anything besides what corporate says. They will tell you to do something one week and the process is totally different the next. Wait til you find out about VC leads. Boy those are a pain. Who wants to call a customer 5 times in one day and send 2 emails? Talk about harassment. Anyways, try to get out of here ASAP. Go for an AE or corporate career, better yet go somewhere else
cons: If customers stop shipping with UPS then it hurts your bonus even though you can’t do anything about it. DAP will take your accounts, the ‘realignments’ will take your accounts, both of which will hurt your bonus. You are required to make a certain amount of dials per day amongst other customer service things but this doesn’t directly impact your bonus. You have to cater to your higher performing customers so they don’t leave, but once they do too good you’ll lose them to an AE. I really think this position will be eliminated in the next couple of years. Customers can just open a DAP account and get better discounts than what we can offer. Our job is pointless after that. Good luck!

job_title: PT Operations Supervisor in Englewood, CO
pros:
- FT hours (40+) available. Job description says 5.5hrs 5x/wk, but realistically it's 6-8hrs 5-6x/wk. OT kicks in at 40.
- Decent benefits. I've used tuition reimbursement as an hourly and management to continue attending school.
cons: There's no sugarcoating this gig: either you're up for a physically challenging job in a productivity-driven environment with reasonable compensation, or you're not. Yes, this is a management position and the primary responsibility is supervising hourly union employees, but this remains a very physically demanding job. You will walk 5-10 miles on concrete every day, and your feet will hurt. You will be lifting large, awkward, 70-150lb packages, and your arms will hurt. This is an open warehouse in CO with some exterior work, so you will be both freezing and burning throughout the year. You will come home exhausted and filthy with box grime and sweat. Typical shift is 0300ish-1000ish, changes weekly based on forecasted workload, but start time will be around midnight or earlier during most of Nov and Dec. Don't take this job if you aren't ready to be pushed every night.

review_title: Too many packages, not enough people.

review_title: Fast Paced and hard work, but not bad
pros: Amazing benefits, off early in the day. I work preload so it's easy for me to get 5 hrs a day. Anything over 5 is over time, and I typically work 5.5hrs. The 6th punch in a week is also overtime. I work M-F so when I pick up Saturday I get 7 hours of overtime every week.
cons: Boxes come down that weigh 150lbs and nobody is around to help get them off the belt as they come by. You don't have time to ask for help, and they really frown upon letting boxes pass you. It's hard to make sure your being careful with your body when you lift heavy boxes because of how fast paced it is. I go home pretty exhausted. Sometimes managers disappear and I can't leave my area to find help with my scanner or when I need a new marker or tape. You have a ten minute break after 2 hours of working, and it's hard to get a snack and use the bathroom in that time. Everyone in the hub is doing the same thing so the lines can be long. Leaving for a bathroom break while boxes are coming down is not easy and can leave you coming back and catching up. Also, if you are a hard worker you get used and pick up the slack for lazy workers. It's easy to get resentful and frustrated. No A/C in the hub, and with Texas heat & humidity you will be soaked with sweat and dirt by the end of your shift.

job_title: Package Handler in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
Overtime starts after only 6hrs into a shift.
Weekly pay.
SOLID health insurance for permanent employees, & some good career opportunities despite rampant exploitation.
Get buff super fast. 
Solid drilling on safe lifting, 
but not always best when actually providing lift assists.
cons:
Their ad for seasonal work lied about the pay (stated 13p/h, actually 11p/h)
They admitted this discrepancy in advertised pay to all new hires during orientation.
HR then lied that we would receive back pay for the wage difference once their Teamsters Union ratified the raise.... 
It's been a few years. 
It got ratified. 
Never received that pay.
MGMT assured seasonal workers had solid chance of permanent employment, 
that at the very least there'd be work thru winter peak season, into February. 
My teammates dropped out like flies due to shite conditions. 
Those who remained by the Holidays were fired by surprise, en-masse, on Christmas Eve.
Their clock-in system is also designed for wage-theft. 
If you clock in before your shift time starts (morning, afternoon, & twilight shifts generally start & end at specific times- but extend thru peak season), you will not receive that pay unless specifically instructed to by MGMT- with a catch.
Even if instructed by MGMT to clock in early (we were.), you had to hound your area's supes to ensure your timing sheet reflected correct hours & not the automatic 4 or 5- otherwise you'd be SOL.
Longest personal shift as a package handler was about 10 hours...
Not bad, except....
No matter how long you work, you get ONE 10 min break. 
& They cut that 10 min break short every time (& I do mean every time) for "PSA" group meets.
You can't trust a damn thing anybody says, but somehow I actually would work there again. Good experiences are possible.
Just document EVERYTHING.

review_title: This is nobody's dream job, but overall it's OK.
pros:
- Simple, almost anyone could do it
- Keeps you physically active
- Decent pay, plus potential for double-shifting / overtime
- Great insurance after 1 year of employment
- Tuition reimbursement under certain conditions
- Vacation / optional days that increase depending on how many years you have worked there
cons:
- Extremely repetitive and uninteresting
- Potential for serious injury
- Tough on your body, especially your lower back
- Very low incentive to work hard. It's also very difficult to be fired, even when it is totally deserved. Some employees take advantage of this and do the absolute bare minimum to stay employed.
- Favoritism / nepotism among management

review_title: You get what you ask for
job_title: On Road Supervisor in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Free uniforms and a once a month direct deposit pay
cons: Full Time Supervisors in the Package Operations are abused. You are a salary position and if you are working in a center that relies on other operations to succeed, prepare to hate your job. Average work week is 60 hours. On Road monthly pay is around 78k a year. Prepare for 65-70 hours a week. They will steal your soul. I am sure some hubs are great, the smaller ones. You make less than the drivers but are to fill in when they dont show. You are expected to train them. You are instructed to discipline them, only to realize the Union makes it impossible to fire anyone. Saturday operations for a supervisor start at 0745 and end when the last driver returns. This is 14-16 hours later. Some union employees feel that they work for the Union, get paid by the Union. The are not loyal to the company and will screw it whenever they can. UPS is a mess and will continue to suffer financially due to the concessions that they provide to the hourly employees. Free Health, Pension, and up to $40 an hour. Driver will make 100-120 K in pay in 5 years, while management make 96k after years and years of nonsense.

job_title: Operations Supervisor in Madison Heights, MI
pros:
Insurance that is given & offered (extra)
-Health
-Dental
-Vision. 
-Pets. (Extra)
-Home/Auto. (Extra)
-Life
+more (extra)

-UPS helps pay college tuition/classes as well as books needed. (Offered to PT supervisors & hourly employees)

- UPS helps supervisors & hourly employees with -Attorneys for legal help (if needed)
- Therapy (mental/addiction)
- Housing if applicable
- Transportation if applicable
A few more resources for life needs

Year 1 being a part-time supervisors. 
Numbers based strictly off 1 year.

- 2 weeks paid vacation (selection based on seniority) does not roll over year to year

- 5 paid option days. Does not roll over year to year

- Starting hourly rate $20.10 .

- Yearly (April) raises based off performance. (%)

- Guaranteed 27-1/2 hrs per week.
cons:
Part-time supervisor cons at UPS.

- Pay for your insurance(s)
(UPS pays for hourlys basic insurance(s)

- Overtime over 8 hours per day
(Hourly employees Overtime after 5-1/2 hours per day)

-Overtime over 40 hours per week.
(Hourly employees get overtime when working over 27-1/2 hours per week)
-----Overtime pay is time and a half per hr-----

- Working 6 days in a week as a part-time supervisor, you don't get that "6th day" bonus.
Example: If and when hourly employees at UPS work Monday - Saturday, that Saturday the employee is paid time and a half that entire shift regardless of total weekly hours worked that week. If you are a Part-Time supervisor this doesn't apply to you.

High stress

pros:
-They pay well; I have to give them that. 

-Many opportunities to move around the company to land in a team that you like, doing work that you enjoy.
cons:
-The right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing. Constantly changing priorities and tasks. Most of the time, I don't know what I'll be doing day to day, or even hour to hour within the same day. 

-While it didn't start out this way, my job has devolved into a perpetual fire drill. I almost never get to take lunch anymore because there's always some fire to put out, and my hours are steadily getting longer and longer.

-Project plans? Milestones? Deadlines? Your deadline is ASAP and your project plan is don't screw up. 

-All too frequently, some one-off analysis you only had 2 hours to slam out becomes the basis for some greater project, and now the VP is quoting it in meetings, and all future work you do for the next 6 months has to tie out to that thing you did on the fly when you should have been taking your lunch.

-Little appetite for change or nuance, and a huge emphasis on not surprising people. If base data updates or methodology improves, too bad, continue using the outdated (i.e. less accurate) version of your analyses. We dare not surprise the Big Boss with numbers that were different from the ones we showed him two months ago.

pros: Pay is well for the work
cons: At the Halethrorpe, MD location just outside of Baltimore, my pay check was cut and my hours were entered into the system incorrectly on purpose by a corrupt section supervisor. The building is old and hot , no heat on the trucks in the winter time. The work is taxing to the body and you end up working most trucks by yourself and when they ask you to help another truck, your truck messes up.

pros:
Benefits are by far the best offered by any employer.
Pay is good when you hit top step
Union protection
cons:
-UPS expects us to work fast, in fact they tell you exactly how long it should take to complete a route(not considering weather, traffic, poorly loaded truck). These times are almost impossible for the average worker to hit, unless you cut corners with regards to safety, which is also a priority of theirs. Making it almost impossible to satisfy management because either you work safe, or fast.

-There is literally no incentive to work hard. At UPS there are 2 types of drivers, guys who want OT and guys who wanna go the **** home. The guys who want the OT, work at a safe and slower pace. They cannot be fired for poor performance, so they don't care how long it takes to complete a route. I'm one of the guys who wanna go home, I work at a nice pace, and try my best to achieve their ridiculous time expectations, I usually finish my route(depending on the route) by 6:00 just enough for me to get home by 7. LOL. If you work hard and finish early, they reward you by making you go and take 20 stops off of a driver who works slower. This leads to the moral of the story. There is no incentive to work hard. If you work slow, you cant get fired, and you get overtime. If you work hard, you do more stops, then get told to go and help a slow driver. So you and the slow driver finish at the same exact time, but they just did 50 less stops than you. This company uses you and does not care about you.

-Starting pay is 20.50 an hour. This may sound decent, but when you realize how much work and stress you have every day, this is far from fair.

-Parking the trucks

-Working on Saturdays

-Literally no diversity, everyone here is white and miserable

-Probably a whole lot more

-So simply put, If you are single and are looking to spend most of your day working, this is a job for you. If you have a family, want to make it to the baseball games, be home for dinner, go to the gym, or do literally anything other than work. Trust me, and continue your job search else where.

pros: Not much besides the good insurance.

review_title: Tons of internal red tape, clunky processes, lots of "you should be grateful for your job"
pros:
Currently have the flexibility of working from home with "return to the office" based on personal comfort with that (but that is not the case for employees in other parts of the country).

Customer interaction is generally positive, except for the instances where I'm held responsible for something completely out of my control.
cons:
The internal red tape and corporate gas lighting is a lot sometimes. The corporation is going through a "transformation" that has made folks wonder about their future at UPS, and question their loyalty over the years (jobs are being cut with little fanfare). The "transformation" also makes it clear that our real customers are stockholders, not shippers. As with many corporations, decisions are made by executives who don't have to use their own services and haven't had boots on the ground in years and are out of touch with the reality of the day-to-day of most of their employees.

Internal mobility is limited, and employees who express interest in moving to other departments are sometimes "blacklisted" in their current department.

Salaries in some departments are some of the lowest across the industry, which is supposed to be countered with other "perks" (like the management incentive program) but it often doesn't pan out that way.

job_title: Package Handler in Las Vegas, NV
pros: After working for a year, you do get benefits. The union is meant to watch your back and they do intend to do it, but it will be on you to learn everything you can about how and when to get in contact with them. If they're looking for drivers, you can actually move up into a really decent paying position quickly.
cons:
Zero training in my group (They legitimately explained to us that we weren't going to finish the mandatory training process and asked us to sign documentation saying otherwise.) 

Management will do everything they can to keep you separate from union officials, and go out of their way to keep you in the dark about your rights as an employee. They will then make every attempt to violate them.

Safety is an afterthought. I legitimately had a coworker lose a thumb. These cons had more to do with my immediate supervisor and his direct superiors than the company itself though, so keep that in mind.

pros: The work is relatively straightforward and manageable, if a little repetitive. The hourly pay is good, and the hiring process was quick.
cons: Apparently, Human Resources does not communicate with management about their staffing needs. I was told upon starting I would be working five days a week, but that I would be sent home early if there wasn't enough work at the facility until I worked long enough to join the Union. Instead, I worked only one day a week and I was sent home several days in a row without being allowed to work at all, due to several "slow" days. Finally, I was informally laid off by my supervisor without a clear reason. Considering said supervisor had spent my whole time there referring to me by the wrong name, I'm not sure he had a reason. Human Resources agreed situation was unfair, but they never followed up, even though they promised to. It seems Human Resources/Recruitment hired too many people without asking management if they needed the people. At one point during my training period I was sent home because management couldn't be bothered to find someone to train me. Other people in my training class encountered similar issues. Even as they lay people off for the excuse of overstaffing, they're still hiring new people.

pros: Benefits are great, pay goes up the longer you're working there with some of the senior members making around 100,000 a year just unloading
cons: Brutal working conditions, especially in the summer. The insides of the trucks you're unloading from would get to around 130f in the summer, since the inside of the truck traps heat. Taking breaks is usually met with some sort of reprimand, even bathroom breaks or stopping to drink water. Multiple people would pass out from heat exhaustion every day. In order to maintain the unloading speed they desired, which I think was 1,200 boxes an hour, you have to step over peoples packages and generally just chuck around peoples orders. Adding onto that, you never know what you're getting in a truck. You could be unloading a bunch of 2 pound packages, or unload an entire truck of 100 pound concrete slabs. Either way, you need to meet the boxes per hour criteria.

review_title: CAN'T SPEAK TO REAL HR PERSON
pros: This is literally the worst company I ever worked for. I never leave reviews because I am appreciative of most companies and understand that no company is perfect but UPS is so horrible that I felt motivated to vent via "Glassdoor", hoping some of my issues will eventually be fixed within the corporation. First and foremost, this company rushes training and sends you to work on the first day. Training consisted of watching an hour-long video that taught you the bare minimum. It didn't even touch on the proper lifting form or teach us how to view our paystub and get into contact with HR if we had any questions. They had us take a test too and didn't even discuss the right answers to the 10-page long packet. Additionally, this company chose to decrease our pay rate randomly even though we're going through inflation. Why decrease our pay rate when you're charging your customer more. Seems kind of greedy and unreasonable in this economy. Lastly, this job does not care about your safety or health! Yes, I understand they give you great health insurance..., but this isn't received until months after you do tons of literally back-breaking work. Let's also talk about the trucks filled with heavy items (over 90lbs) that you're forced to do alone. To make matters worst, these trucks are packed to the roof so you have to risk one of these heavy items collapsing on your head. One of the workers actually got a concussion from these heavy items falling on his head. This company needs a ton of improvement... it's a shame because you would expect better especially considering the fact that you have to pay a union that seems to do nothing to protect workers!
cons:
- Hard to talk to a real HR person or view paystub 
- Poor training 
- Backbreaking work 
- Poor supervisors (Just watch you work and stay on their phones and casually talking to one another)
- Poor safety conditions 
- Poor pay rate 
- Must pay the union dues even though you aren't protected by the unions 
- Lack of PPE (Personal Protection Equipment)

pros: The pros for UPS are limited. In the past years they have gotten better with the changing in attire of being able to wear jeans and the option to have facial hair. However, the only consistent Pro that I have witnessed is the pay seems to be higher than other companies depending on the job task.
cons: Where do I start with Cons for UPS. While pay is more than other companies, it's still not enough for what you must endure during normal time of the year (peak is even more of a joke since the expectation is to work 14+ hour days even when your job is not involved with the direct operation). Also, while old school mentality of how things are to be done is being pushed out by upper management, there are still those that won't budge with this thought process. It makes it very difficult to have a work life balance when your boss is too rigid in their old school upbringing. And if you have been given the green light to work from home by the company, don't bother trying because your boss will deny it. The expectations of the job simply do not balance with the benefits package.

pros:
-$5,000 college tuition per year.
-Low hours if you're in school.
-Can transfer after some time to a better/career job within UPS depending on availability.
cons:
-There are a lot of terrible supervisors at UPS that management doesn't do anything about.
-You have to compete constantly with everyone you work with for more hours. People are sent home throughout the night to save money based on the work flow. Even when you're at the top, you're still making 15-20 hours a week if it isn't peak season and earning $14 hr. If you don't perform, you'll get cut early every night. If they want you gone, they generally wont fire you, but they'll give you less than an hour of work every day until you quit. If you stick around they have an extra body in case a random night has a heavy workload you're still conveniently there. 
-Promotions are based on who sticks around longer and not who's actually good at their job. You get put onto a list and they will just go down the list. Based on availability you can be waiting years to switch jobs. 
-Management always wants more. The better you are, the bigger the workload they'll put onto you until you break.
-This is a constant, hard labor job with no breaks. Stop working and your supervisors will yell at you.
-Retention rate is so low I'm not sure how they keep finding people for this job.
